conclusion: Two objects, A and B, move along the same straight line from the same starting position. Their velocities over time are plotted in a graph.
The graph shows velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis, with two curves: one for A and one for B.
For object A, the velocity increases steadily over time.
For object B, the velocity decreases, reaches a minimum, and then starts increasing again.
There are vertical dashed lines at times t1 and t2, and a red dot on the graph.
The positions at any time t can be found by integrating their velocity functions from time 0 to time t.

premise: The distance between them at any time is the integral of their velocity difference from time 0 to time t.
conclusion: To find when they are farthest apart, find the time t where this distance is maximized.
The distance between them is |position_A(t) - position_B(t)| = |âˆ« from 0 to t (v_A(t) - v_B(t)) dt|.

premise: A is always moving in the positive direction since its velocity is always positive.
conclusion: For B, its velocity dips down to a minimum but doesn't seem to go negative.

premise: Both are moving in the positive direction; there's no overtaking happening where one is moving backwards.
conclusion: The distance between them will keep increasing as long as their velocities are different.

premise: The distance will start decreasing when their velocities become equal and one starts catching up with the other.
conclusion: The point where their velocities are equal is significant.
At time t2, there's a red dot where the two curves seem to intersect, suggesting that at t2, their velocities are equal.

premise: At t2, their velocities are equal, and if B is accelerating more than A, then B will start catching up with A.
conclusion: At time t2, the distance between them is maximized.

premise: From t=0 to t2, A is moving faster than B, so A is pulling away from B.
conclusion: At t2, their separation is changing at the same rate as each other.

premise: After t2, if B's velocity increases faster than A's, then B starts to catch up to A.
conclusion: The distance between them decreases after t2.

premise: After t2, B's velocity is increasing more rapidly than A's.
